response.answer_text: Previously, under feudalism, there was a system of common fields. Common land, including fields, forests, roads, streams, lakes, etc.  Some of the land was owned by the landlord, but not all the land. And even the land owned by the landlord was not owned in the same sense that land is owned now. There were restrictions on what could be done with it: ownership could not be sold, responsibilities came with the ownership, access could not be denied, etc. The commoners lived off the commons.  The fields were organized, divided into parcels, and rotated, so that nobody would ever get the all the best land, and nobody would be left with nothing. This system worked for thousands of years. There was a rich rural economy, spread out. At first, the local lords were of the same culture as the commoners. The same ethnicity. But after centuries of war and conquest, it became quite common for the lords to be different from the people they ruled over. The French ruled over parts of England, or the English ruled over Scotland and Ireland, and so on. The commoners were declared to be an obstacle to progress. Savages. Lazy and dangerous. They were able to work relatively little to live, and enjoyed free time, drinking, playing, etc. But idleness was seen as a vice.  The laborers and others working for wages were seen as a much better option (by the lords). Industrious people, working for their lords. Wages had to be high, and days had to be short. Otherwise, people would simply not accept to work for wages, and live off the commons. This refusal to work for wages was seen as proof of their laziness. The Enclosure acts were passed, progressively. Taking away the commoner’s land, to force them into labor, and to allow the landlord higher profits. The commoners being forced to work, would become more virtuous, avoiding the dangers of idleness, and the vice and immorality it brought. There were many revolts, which were met with violence and repression.  Eventually, all the land was privatized. The landlords right to privatize the land and do with it as they pleased was seen as the only acceptable form of freedom. The freedom to own private property. Capitalism. Without any way of subsistence, the commoners were no longer able to be independent. They were forced into being laborers. Many were evicted from their homes and had to travel to a town, in search of subsistence through meager wages.  Since they had no other options, the commoners-turned-proles were forced into horrible labor conditions, working long days for bare survival wages. Poverty and misery was rampant, while the landlords and factory owners became incredibly rich and wealthy. The term “wage slavery” is an oximoron… I hear the collective gasps!!! And can feel the contemptuous lightning bolt gazes of the collective as they gear up for scathing repudiation, and wordy vehemently denouncing rebuttals. But the reality is: A wage is remuneration.an employee is employed by an employer. And as such the employee receives wage as remuneration from the employer for the employee’s labor at the behest of the employer.A slavery is an individual is enslaved as property of an owner, and receives no remuneration for the labor the slave owner demands the slave to perform.Being an employee is a choice. Being a slave is not.An employee has a choice to, at will, look at their employer and terminate their employment with the employer.A slave does not have the choice to at will look at their enslaver and terminate their status as property to their owner.If an employee resists their employers demand; the employer may terminate the employee’s employment, and the employer and former employee continue life on separate paths.If the slave resists their owners demand; the owner terminates and disposes of their property…. the former slave owner continues on a life path.An employee receives a wage, and is never property of their employer. A slave never receives a wage, and is property of their owner.Many individuals and parties, (who are either disenchanted with the employee/employer economic model, or are enchanted by the communal/shared labor and benefits economic model), liken the inequalities of the employee/employer relationship to the slave/slave owner relationship…. The reality is there is no commonality between the two distinct, and poignantly different relationships… one is a choice, the other is not. “Just my humble opinion of course….”

“How did wage slavery become a thing?” Through the 1800s, Marx’ and Malthus’ predictions of mass uprising and starvation didn’t happen. As automation and industrialization shifted labor from farming-by-hand to employment, people’s lives dramatically improved. Per-capita production increased for everything, life spans increased. Diseases, malnutrition, infant mortality, all decreased dramatically. The Marxists looked around and were stumped about how to motivate people to listen to the Socialist cause when every prediction of the evils of Capitalism were not just not occurring, the Socialist cause was being left in the dustbin of history. And so was invented the idea of “Wage Slavery”, that somehow people were being exploited by being paid for their work in a mutually satisfactory way. This is where the myth of an “adversarial” relationship based on an arbitrary (and false) distinction between management and labor was created, to twist any valid concerns by employees of a firm into support for the Socialist cause, rather than focusing on the concerns themselves. The “Wage Slavery” and adversarial attitude has been pushed ever since by those who gain power for themselves through that propaganda. That is how “Wage Slavery” became a thing. Anyone who believes it is being played for a sucker.

Now technically, wage slavery doesn’t and didn’t ever exist. The slave has to do something and his dream is to find a way where he doesn’t. The wage slave asks he be allowed to do the work, and his greatest fear is apt to be to be fired, and freed from being a wage slave. The slave and the wage slave share the feature of somebody pushing them around, but the wage slave is the one who can walk out the door at will. The “wage slave”, as a term, appeared when English 1st became a language, but it refers to a condition that arouse with specialization of work. Somebody had to judge your work and pay you. He became the boss, and you the worker.
